heading.title: Practice and procedural guide: Local Court Practice Guide
Practice and procedural guide: Local Court Practice Guide

p.text: Editor's note: Unless otherwise stated, all references to sections and Parts are to the Civil Procedure Act 2005 (CPA) and the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 (UCPR), and the Local Courts Act 2007 (LCA 2007). The references to paragraph number thus: “[285,100]”, or “[LCA s 65.55]” refer to the appropriate paragraph in Ritchie’s Uniform Civil Procedure NSW.
Legislation cited in [26,000] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100.
(CTH) Competition and Consumer Act 2010 Pt IVB, s 86(2), (3).
(NSW) Fair Trading Act 1987 s 68.
(NSW) Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 22.
(NSW) Contracts Review Act 1980 s 7(1)(a).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 6.30(3).

row.entry: The jurisdictional limit of the court is $100,000
However, the limit is $60,000 in claims for damages arising from personal injury and death
Despite s 29(1)(a) , the court has jurisdiction to hear and determine a "money claim" for an amount not exceeding 20% of the court's jurisdictional limit if a memorandum of consent is filed
LCA 2007 s 31
“Money claim” means ‘a claim for recovery of any debt, demand or damage (whether liquidated or unliquidated)’.
LCA 2007 s 29A
A Local Court sitting in its Small Claims Division has jurisdiction to hear and determine claims (as above) in which the amount claimed does not exceed $10,000.
This includes actions for detention of goods.
The court's Small Claims Division is considered at:

Interest up to judgment under CPA s 100 is to be disregarded for the purpose of determining whether the maximum jurisdictional amount has been exceeded and whether the court sitting in a Division has jurisdiction or not.

The Local Court has jurisdiction under this Act “with respect to any matter arising under Pt IVB in respect of which a civil proceeding is instituted by a person other than the Minister or the Commission”, that is in respect of the breach of Industry Codes. However, the Local Court can only grant a remedy that the court is able to grant under the law of NSW (eg damages within the limits of its pecuniary jurisdiction and not the other remedies in the Act).
Competition and Consumer Act 2010 (Cth) s 86(2) , (3) noted at [LCA07 Pt 3.10]

As a court of competent jurisdiction, the court has jurisdiction under the Fair Trading Act 1987 s 68 (proceedings for offences), in similar circumstances to those arising under the Trade Practices Act 1974 (Cth).
Fair Trading Act 1987 s 68

Since a debt arising as a result of money loaned by one party to another during a marriage does not arise out of the marital relationship, but out of the transaction itself, the court has jurisdiction in respect of such a debt.
See note at [LCA07 s 30.55]

entry.emph: Interaction with Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001

row.entry: A court has no jurisdiction to hear or determine an issue which is not before the court at the time when an application is made to the Tribunal, and vice versa.
Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 22 at [285,100], behind guide card "Other Legislation". See also note at [LCA07 s 30.35]

The court has power to exercise power and to grant relief under Contracts Review Act 1980 s 7(1)(a) only if application is made for the exercise of such jurisdiction in the course of proceedings that are being heard in a Local Court.
LCA 2007 s 32
Contains provision for service of documents on companies
Corporations Act 2001 (Cth) s 109X
Confers jurisdiction under the Act on a Local Court
Provides for the transfer of proceedings in a lower court
The Local Court has jurisdiction to deal with proceedings under the Property (Relationships) Act 1984
Jurisdiction conferred by the Civil Procedure Amendment (Application of Act) Regulation 2005, commenced 15 August 2005.
As to the substitution of a legal representative after a party dies, see
UCPR r 6.30(3)

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,005] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 56, s 56(2), s 56(3)–(4), s 57, s 58, s 59, s 64.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 2.

row.entry: The overriding purpose of the CPA and the UCPR is to facilitate the just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in the proceedings, a purpose the court must give effect to when it exercises any power given to it by the CPA or the UCPR.
CPA s 56 ; Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 3.3

A party to proceedings is under a duty to assist the court to further the overriding purpose and a solicitor or barrister must not, by his or her conduct, cause his or her client to be put in breach of this duty.
CPA s 56(3)–(4) ; Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 3.6

Proceedings must be case managed, having regard to the just determination of proceedings; the efficient disposal of the business of the court; the efficient use of available judicial and administrative resources; and the timely disposal of those proceedings, and all other proceedings in the court, at a cost affordable by the respective parties.
CPA s 57
The court can give directions and make orders designed to achieve the above objects.
UCPR Pt 2

The court is required to act in accordance with the dictates of justice in deciding whether to make any order or direction for the management of proceedings, including orders for amendment or adjournment, and may take into account factors such as degree of difficulty or complexity, and the degree of injustice that would be suffered by the parties. The decision in Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; [1997] HCA 1; BC9700005 , now over a decade old and the subject of numerous statutory and regulatory modifications, must now be understood as operating subject to the statutory duty imposed upon the courts by CPA s 56(2) , which requires the court in mandatory terms — “must seek” — to give effect to the overriding purpose — to “facilitate the just, quick and cheap resolution of the real issues in the proceedings” — when exercising any power under the Act or Rules. That duty constitutes a significant qualification of the power to grant leave to amend a pleading under CPA s 64 : Dennis v Australian Broadcasting Corp [2008] NSWCA 37; BC200802105 at [28], [29] .
CPA s 58 , esp s 58(2)(b)

The practice, procedure and interlocutory processes of the court shall have as their goal the elimination of any lapse of time from the date of initiation of proceedings to their final determination beyond that reasonably required for interlocutory activities essential to the fair and just determination of the issues bona fide in contention between the parties and the preparation of the case for trial.
CPA s 59

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,010] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 1.22–1.25.

row.entry: If you wish to raise a matter arising under the Commonwealth constitution or its interpretation, you must file a notice of constitutional matter and serve a copy of the notice on all other parties and the Attorneys-General of the Commonwealth, the States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, and file an appropriate affidavit of Service
UCPR rr 1.22–1.25

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,020] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 rr 4.2, r 4.2A, r 4.3(3A).

row.entry: As to the information which must be contained in documents filed, see
UCPR rr 4.2 and following
As to certification of reasonable prospects of success for the purposes of the Legal Profession Act 2004, see
UCPR r 4.3(3A)
As to list of parties where there are more than 2 plaintiffs or more than 2 defendants, see
UCPR r 4.2A
The prescribed form of list of parties is
Form 2

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,025] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 5.2(1)(a), r 5.2(1)(b), r 5.2(2)(a), r 5.2(2)(b), rr 5.3, 5.4, r 5.6, r 6.4(1)(c).

row.entry: If you are, or are acting for, the plaintiff and are unsure about a prospective defendant’s identity or whereabouts, consider making an application for preliminary discovery and inspection
UCPR Pt 5

p.text: You will need to show:

row.entry: that you have made reasonable inquiries and are unable to sufficiently ascertain the identity or whereabouts of a person for the purpose of commencing proceedings against that person;
UCPR r 5.2(1)(a)
that some other person may have information or may have or have had possession of a document or thing that tends to assist in ascertaining the identity or whereabouts of that person.

p.text: The court may make an order for

row.entry: a person to attend court to be examined; and/or
the discovery of documents;
ancillary order — security for costs; costs and other expenses.
Such an application is made by summons.
r 6.4(1)(c); Form 4A, 4B

level.toc-caption: [26,030] Commencement of proceedings — acting for the plaintiff

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,030] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Commencement of proceedings — acting for the plaintiff

row.entry: Should you commence proceedings by statement of claim or summons?
Note: For the purposes of the issue of originating process, there is no longer any distinction between an ordinary statement of claim and a statement of liquidated claim.
Proceedings required to be commenced by statement of claim are set out in‥
UCPR r 6.3 ; Form 3A, 3B
Proceedings required to be commenced by summons are set out in‥
r 6.4; Form 4A, 4B

In general terms, it has been said that “a statement of claim is appropriate where there are contested issues of fact and a summons where there are not”, even though there are some proceedings where the issues are comparatively simple, which are always tried on summons, even though there is a factual contest (for example, Family provision proceedings).
Hamilton J, “Nuts and bolts for Judicial Officers”, Judicial Commission of NSW, 16 August 2005.
If the wrong process is chosen, see:
As to who may commence and carry on proceedings (natural person, corporation and in certain instances in the Local Court, a commercial agent with respect to debt collection see
As to representative proceedings, see
rr 7.4 ff
As to persons under legal incapacity, see
rr 7.13 ff
As to the circumstances in which a party may take a step in the proceedings without having filed a statement of claim or summons or entered an appearance
These comprise:
• defendant applying to set aside original process;
• plaintiff applying for order in urgent case before commencement of proceedings;
• defendant making application in relation to setting aside or enforcement of judgment
A non-party who has not filed a notice of motion must file an address for service
The formal requirements of a statement of claim and summons are set out in
UCPR rr 6.12 –6.17
• In particular, the nature of the relief claimed by the plaintiff must be specified;
• costs must be specifically claimed;
• exemplary damages and aggravated compensatory damages must be specifically claimed
• an order for interest up to judgment must be specifically claimed
As to other formal requirements (notice to defendant, summons to specify return day, etc), see:
As to the preparation and form of documents generally see
UCPR Pt 4, Forms 3A, 3B, 4A, 4B and 6
As to amendment of statement of claim allowed once within 28 days of filing but not after a date for hearing has been fixed unless the court orders otherwise, see
The form of pleading (generally) is covered by
• pleadings must be divided into paragraphs
• they must contain facts, not evidence
• they must be as brief as the nature of the case allows

• If documents or spoken words are referred to in a pleading, the effect of the document or spoken words must, so far as material, be stated, and the precise terms of the document or spoken words must not be stated, except in so far as those terms are themselves material
• Certain facts must not be pleaded (for example, if the fact is presumed by law to be true, or the burden of disproving the fact lies on the other party)
• Conditions precedent are presumed to be met
• In a statement of claim, the plaintiff must plead specifically any matter that, if not pleaded specifically, may take the defendant by surprise
Common money counts: These may be pleaded in short form

entry.emph: A pleading should not claim an amount for unliquidated damages

row.entry: An exception is that, in the Local (or District) Court, a claim may be made for unliquidated damages if the claim is for motor vehicle repairs or for damage sustained as a result of a motor vehicle accident. Such claims are deemed “liquidated”.
Particulars (generally) are covered by:
UCPR Pt 15
• A court can order that particulars be supplied
• A party must give particulars of any allegation of fraud, misrepresentation, breach of trust, willful default, undue influence or any condition of mind
• As to service of special particulars in claims for personal injuries, proceedings under the Compensation to Relatives Act 1987, see

When paying a filing fee, a person must advise the court if the proceedings to which the fee relates are being carried on by a corporation in the name of a natural person pursuant to a right of subrogation
UCPR r 4.16
As to service of documents generally, see:
UCPR Pts 10 and 11
Unless the court otherwise orders, all documents filed must be served on all “active parties”
UCPR r 10.1
An “active party” is a party who has an address for service other than a party against whom no further claim in the proceedings subsists
UCPR Dictionary

In the Local Court, originating process may be served personally; it may be left, addressed to the defendant, at the defendant’s residential or business address with a person apparently over the age of 16 years; or it may be served by post by the court
(The Local Court must serve a defence on behalf of a party)
As to notices given or served by the court and service of defence by the court, see:
As to the various methods of service, see:
As to service on an unregistered business:
As to service on a registered business:
As to service on a person under a legal incapacity:
As to acceptance of service by a solicitor:
As to substituted and informal service:
As to service by filing:
As to personal service on an inmate of a correctional centre:
As to personal service on a person who “keeps house”:
As to how personal service is effected generally:
As to waiver of objection to service by filing a document in reply to a document alleged to have been served on a party, see:
As to service where the defendant is outside NSW but within Australia:
Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth), ss 15, 16 at [415,110] f.
As to service interstate on companies and registered bodies, other bodies corporate and on a body politic, see:
Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth), ss 9, 10, 15 at [415,050] f.
As to proof of service interstate, including service by post, service on a company, registered body or other body corporate and dispensing with certain requirements of proof, see:
Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) s 11 at [415,060]
Originating process is valid for service for 6 months after the date on which it was filed

But if the originating process was filed prior to 15 August 2005, it will be valid for service for 12 months after the expiry of a period of 28 days after service of the statement of claim on the defendant, unless that period is extended by the court (for further elaboration, see below)
Civil Procedure Regulation 2005, cl 18. The prior situation was governed by LC(CC)R Pt 11 r 1(1)
Proceedings commenced in the Local Court are on the Court’s own motion and order dismissed if within 9 months after a statement of claim has been filed:
(a) a defence or cross claim is not filed, or
(b) a default judgment is not entered, or
UCPR r 12.9(2); PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 7.1.
(c) the proceedings are not otherwise disposed of.
No such order is made if there are any Notices of Motion or other applications pending.
UCPR r 12.9(4); PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 7.2
UCPR r 16.2.

A defendant is "in default" for the purposes of this rule if he or she: (a) fails to file a defence with the time limited by rule 14.3 or within such further time as the court allows; (b) fails to file an affidavit verifying his or her defence in accordance with the Rules or if (c) the court orders the defence to be struck out.

A defendant is not "in default" if he or she has: (a) made a payment towards a liquidated claim under rule 6.17; (b) filed an acknowledgement of claim under rule 20.33; or (c) filed a defence outside time but before the plaintiff files an application for default judgment.
The prescribed form of notice of payment under r 6.17 is
Form 34

entry.emph: What is the procedure for applying for default judgment?

row.entry: Unless the court otherwise orders, an application for default judgment must be accompanied by an affidavit of service (unless the Local Court has served the Statement of Claim), and an affidavit in support of the application stating when and how the originating process was served on the defendant

entry.emph: What kinds of claims can be encompassed on claims for default judgment?

row.entry: Apart from liquidated claims, default judgments are now available on claims for possession of land, detention of goods, claims for unliquidated damages and mixed claims

For the purposes of default judgment, although the general rule is that a pleading must not claim an amount of unliquidated damages, in the Local (or District) Court, a claim may be made for unliquidated damages if the claim is for motor vehicle repairs or for damage sustained as a result of a motor vehicle accident. Such claims are deemed “liquidated”.

This means that, where the plaintiff's claim is a property damage claim arising from negligence in a motor vehicle accident, you should file an affidavit of a repairer or valuer as to the quantum of repairs or as to the value, less salvage of, the plaintiff's motor vehicle together with an affidavit of the owner (plaintiff) linking up the damage sustained in the accident with the damage referred to in the repairer's affidavit.
For default judgment on claims made under r 14.13(2), see
Forms — Default judgment for detention of goods
Form 37
Notice of Motion — Default judgment for liquidated claim
Form 38
Notice of Motion — Default judgment for unliquidated claim
Form 39
Default judgment for costs alone, see:
Judgment not limited by plaintiff’s claims for relief where defendant is in default

level.toc-caption: [26,030.35] Where the defendant files a defence

heading.title: Where the defendant files a defence

entry.emph: If the defendant applies on motion for a change of venue under Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 10

row.entry: If you do not agree to the proposed change, you may, within 14 days from the date the notice of listing was sent, file and serve an affidavit in response.
P N Civ 1 of 2011, cl 10.5
The issue is determined in chambers

entry.emph: Applying to strike out the defence

row.entry: Is the defendant's defence adequate? Does it disclose reasonable grounds of defence? In order to be struck out under r 14.28 it must be obviously defective: Brimson v Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 937 . If it is manifest that there is no real issue to be tried, apply for summary judgment. The circumstances in which a court may strike out pleadings are set out at

entry.emph: Defendant defends as to part only of plaintiff's claim

row.entry: Note that part confessions are no longer available. A defendant who wishes to acknowledge part of a liquidated claim must plead this matter in the defence. This is the effect of
Transitional: However, as regards existing part confessions, LC(CC) R Pt 12 r 2(7) continues to apply as if it had not been repealed
Civil Procedure Regulation 2005 Cl 16

Apply for particulars if you consider it necessary to do so. If they are not supplied, you may apply for an order for the supply of same and/or a statement of the nature of the case upon which the defendant relies. Conversely, you should respond to any request for particulars to avoid an application for their supply:

If the case involves building and/or technical claims, such as allegations of defective workmanship or materials or a claim for extras, prepare your side of the Scott Schedule and forward it to the defendant for completion. If defective workmanship or materials or a claim for extras form part of the defendant's case or cross-claim, request them to prepare a Scott Schedule.
The approved form is:
Form 13 “Scott Schedule”

level.toc-caption: [26,035] Defending proceedings — acting for the defendant

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,035] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 146, s 149, s 22, Sch 6.

heading.title: Defending proceedings — acting for the defendant

row.entry: You may file a notice of appearance, but if you file a defence, you are taken to have entered an appearance in the proceedings:
UCPR r 6.9
Applications for a change of venue are provided for under
UCPR r 8.2

entry.emph: Applications for transfer between the various tiers of courts

row.entry: CPA Pt 9 and UCPR Pt 44
(This aspect is dealt with in more detail below at [26,065] ).Note that proceedings may now be transferred by the Supreme Court direct to the Local Court
CPA s 146
If a higher court chooses to transfer proceedings to a lower court, then the lower court has and may exercise all of the jurisdiction of the higher court in relation to those proceedings
CPA s 149

entry.emph: Applying to strike out the originating process

row.entry: Is the originating process adequate? Does it have a reasonable cause of action? In order to be struck out under r 14.28 it must be obviously defective: Brimson v Rocla Concrete Pipes Ltd [1982] 2 NSWLR 937 . If it is manifest that no cause of action is disclosed, apply for summary judgment. The circumstances in which a court may strike out pleadings are set out at:
Apply for particulars if you consider it necessary to do so. If they are not supplied, you may apply for an order under:
The time limited for filing a defence is 28 days after service of the statement of claim or such other time as the court directs
UCPR r 14.3
The approved form is:
Form 7A, 7B: “Defence”
If the plaintiff has pleaded a common money count, you may file a notice requiring the plaintiff to plead the facts on which he or she relies in full
The prescribed form is:
Form 16: “Notice to plead facts”
Note that a plaintiff may file a reply to a defence only by leave of the court
There is no provision for verification of pleadings in the Local Court
Service: A defence must be served on the other parties, on behalf of the party by whom it was filed, by an officer of the Local Court

Note that upon the filing of a first defence, the proceedings will be given a first Call-over within 6 weeks of the defence filing date, so time is of the essence. If, there is an application for the proceedings to be transferred to another Local Court, the proceedings will be given a first Call-over date within 6 weeks of the defendant’s application for transfer being determined
PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 12.1
Acknowledgment of the whole of a liquidated claim: If the plaintiff’s claim is liquidated, you may, if you wish, file an acknowledgment of the whole of the claim
The procedure is not available if you have filed a defence or the plaintiff has filed an application for default judgment
On the filing of the acknowledgment, judgment is to be entered for the whole of the amount of the claim, whereupon all the plaintiff’s claims in the proceedings are discharged
This procedure replaces the full confession procedure previously available in the Local Court
Part confessions are no longer available: a defendant who wishes to acknowledge part of a liquidated claim, must do so in the defence
Transitional: However, as regards existing part confessions, LC(CC) R Pt 12 r 2(7) continues to apply as if it had not been repealed
Civil Procedure Regulation 2005 cl 16
The approved form is:
Form 35A “Acknowledgment of Liquidated Claim”
You must apply for change of venue when filing defence
PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 10.1
The right to bring a cross-claim is found in:
CPA s 22
As to the manner in which cross-claims are made, see:
UCPR Pt 9
Note that now cross-claim only applies to the claim itself, not to the document by which it is made, which is referred to as a ‘statement of cross-claim’
A cross-claim may be made by filing:
(a) a statement of cross-claim in proceedings commenced by statement of claim; or
(b) a cross-summons in proceedings commenced by summons,
The approved forms of Statement of Cross-claim and Cross-summons are respectively
Forms 9 and 10

A person against whom a cross-claim is made does not have to enter an appearance if he or she is already a party to the proceedings in which the cross-claim is made, and has entered an appearance in those proceedings
Unless the court otherwise orders, proceedings on a cross-claim are to be carried on together with the proceedings from which the cross-claim arises
However, a cross-claim may be separately prosecuted

Note that the third party procedure provided for in LC(CC)R Pt 19 is no longer available. Such claims should now be made by statement of cross-claim. Proceedings commenced under the former third party procedure may be continued under the transitional provisions in the
CPA Sch 6 cll 5, 10
Service: If a cross-defendant is an active party, personal service of a statement of claim or cross-summons is not required
As to service on new parties, see:

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,040] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 17.5, r 20.14, r 20.2, r 20.34, r 20.6, r 21.2, rr 21.8, 22.13, r 22.2, r 36.1A.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 26, s 27, s 29(1), s 29(2), s 32.

The following principles are extracted from an address on the new procedures given by Justice Hamilton entitled “Nuts and bolts for judicial officers”, Judicial Commission of New South Wales, 16 August 2005.

row.entry: Discovery is provided for in
UCPR Pt 21
In accordance with case management principles, discovery must be obtained by order of the court; there is no provision allowing discovery to be required by notice

The form of order for discovery which is provided for is an order for discovery of documents within a class or classes specified in the order or of one or more samples of documents within such a class
An order for discovery may not be made in respect of a document unless the document is relevant to a fact in issue
There is no provision for the making of an order for general discovery
As to admission of documents discovered see
UCPR r 17.5
Interrogatories are provided for in:
UCPR Pt 22
These are now also to be administered only by order specifying the particular interrogatories
The court must not order interrogatories unless it is satisfied that the order is necessary at the time it is made
In personal injuries cases, discovery and interrogatories may be ordered only if the court finds that there are "special reasons" for doing so

“Whilst Local Courts now have the power to order discovery and interrogatories, bearing in mind the size of the claims they may now entertain, it is hoped that in the interests of proportionality of costs, such orders will be rarely made”
Hamilton J, 16 August 2005
Mediation is provided for in:
UCPR Pt 20 Div 1
The court may refer any proceedings or part thereof for mediation without the consent of the parties
CPA s 26
PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cll 8.1, 8.3.
Parties are under a duty to participate in good faith in the mediation
CPA s 27
The court may make orders to give effect to any agreement or arrangement arising out of a mediation session
CPA s 29(1)
On an application under s 29(1), any party may call evidence including evidence from the mediator as to the agreement or arrangement reached
CPA s 29(2)
The court may give directions regulating the practice and procedure to be followed at a mediation, including the preparation and service of documents
UCPR r 20.2
A mediator may give directions as to the preparation for, and conduct of, the mediation
CPA s 32

The mediation session must be attended by each party, or, if the party is a body corporate, by someone with authority to settle the proceedings, or an officer of an insurer, if appropriate. A party may be accompanied by a party’s barrister or solicitor
UCPR r 20.6
Arbitration is separately considered in the service at
Procedural aspects governing proceedings referred to arbitration are considered in more detail in this Practice and Procedural Guide below at:
The Court will only refer proceedings to arbitration where there are no complex issues of fact or law and the hearing is estimated to take 3 hours or less
PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 8.4
As to proceddings in the SCD, see
PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 8.5
The Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 to give a Local Court the same jurisdiction as the District Court to deal with certain matters arising under the Act
CPA Sch 5.5; Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 s 4(2)
At any stage of the proceedings, the court may make orders for reference to a referee to report on the whole of the proceedings or on any question arising in the proceedings
UCPR r 20.14
This may occur in disputes involving technical disputes where the selected referee's expertise can be appropriately utilised
Offers of compromise are dealt with in:
As to entry of judgment pursuant to an agreement between the parties, see
The prescribed form of consent/judgment order is
Form 44
As to circumstances in which the defendant may file an acknowledgment of the whole of a liquidated claim, see:
The procedure is not available if the defendant has filed a defence or the plaintiff has filed an application for default judgment
On the filing of the acknowledgment, judgment is to be entered for the whole of the amount of the claim, whereupon all the plaintiff’s claims in the proceedings are discharged
This procedure replaces the full confession procedure previously available in the Local Court
Part confessions are no longer available. A defendant who wishes to acknowledge part of a liquidated claim, must do so in the defence
Transitional: However, as regards existing part confessions, LC(CC) R Pt 12 r 2(7) continues to apply as if it had not been repealed
Civil Procedure Regulation 2005 cl 16
The approved form of acknowledgment of liquidated claim is
Form 35A “Acknowledgment of Liquidated Claim”

level.toc-caption: [26,045] Preparing for the call-over and the hearing

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,045] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 17.2, rr 17.3, 17.4, rr 42.8, 42.9.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 57(1)(a), s 61(3), s 61(4), s 70.
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 4.

heading.title: Preparing for the call-over and the hearing

row.entry: Have you prepared a written summary of your case and sufficient copies of your evidence as required by
Standard Directions Annexure A to PN Civ 1 of 2011, cll 2, 3.
Have particulars been sought and exchanged?
If the claim or cross-claim is being litigated in the General Division, prepare and serve appropriate notices to admit facts, and authenticity of documents
The approved form of notice disputing facts and authenticity of documents is:
(Note that, unless the court otherwise orders, costs are payable when a party proves a fact or the authenticity of a document that has been in dispute)
UCPR rr 42.8 , 42.9

Respond within 14 days to such notices served upon you if you dispute any such facts and authenticity of documents. Otherwise the facts and the authenticity of documents will be deemed admitted. Such an admission may be withdrawn by leave of the court
As to voluntary admission concerning facts and documents that are not in dispute, see:
As to informal proof and admissions, see also:
CPA s 70
EVIDENCE ACT 1995
Have you complied with the various procedural provisions under the Evidence Act 1995 enacted with a view to facilitating the admission of evidence? In particular:

Does your case rely in any way on the admission of first hand hearsay evidence (that is, evidence of a previous representation that was made by a person who had personal knowledge of an asserted fact: s 62 )
Evidence Act 1995 ss 63(2) , 64(2) , 65(2) , (3), (8); s 67 ; Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 4
If so, have you given reasonable notice in writing (14 days in civil matters) of your intention to do so
Note that the Evidence Act also facilitates the admission of evidence in each of the following circumstances:
• contemporaneous statements about a person’s health, feelings, sensations, intention, knowledge or state of mind (s 66A );
• coincidence evidence;
• hearsay evidence (reputation as to age and relationship);
• leave to cross-examine an unfavourable witness;
• evidence of police officer being read or led from a previously written statement;
• proof of voluminous or complex documents by a summary;
• certificates of expert evidence;
• documents in foreign countries; and
• proof of certain matters (including documents, hearsay exceptions and official records) by affidavit or statement.
Note that the Evidence Act 1995 also facilitates the use of requests from one party to another in each of the following circumstances:
• the production of documents or things;

• calling as a witness a specified person believed to be concerned in the production of a specified document or thing, or in whose possession or under whose control a specified document or thing is believed to be or to have been at any time;
• to permit the requesting party adequately and in an appropriate way to examine test or copy the whole or a part of a specified document or thing;
• in relation to a previous representation to call as a witness the person who made the previous representation (see ss 63–65 );
• and in relation to evidence of conviction, to call as a witness a person who gave evidence in the proceeding in which the person was convicted.
Evidence Act 1995 ss 166–169
As to the time limits for making requests, see:
Evidence Act 1995
As to the consequences of a failure or refusal to comply with a request, see:
Evidence Act 1995 s 169

level.toc-caption: [26,045.10] First Call-over, second Call-over/Directions Hearing and Review — Chief Magistrate’s Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011

heading.title: First Call-over, second Call-over/Directions Hearing and Review — Chief Magistrate’s Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011

p.text: The relevant principles are set out in the Chief Magistrates Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, effective 23 March 2011, reissued 7 January 2013. As to online disposal of Directions hearings, see PN 6 of 2008 at [LC 6 of 2008] .

row.entry: As to legal representation at the Pre-trial Review, Call-over and Review, see
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 6

The Standard Directions made at the call-over include filing a written summary of a party’s case and copies of evidence, service of written statements or affidavits of the intended evidence of all witnesses, together with copies of any exhibits
Standard Directions, Annexure A to Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 2.2

The court may order that all or any of a witness’s evidence at a trial must be given by affidavit, or subject to r 31.4 (which deals with cases where the only matters in question are interest; assessment of damages or the value of goods; or costs) by witness statement
UCPR r 31.1(3)

The effect of UCPR rr 31.1(3) and 31.4 is that once the court gives a direction to serve witness statements, the statements of persons called to give evidence stand as their evidence in chief, and parties who have not complied with the direction may not adduce evidence to which the direction relates except with the court’s leave. This aspect is considered in more detail in this Practice and Procedural Guide under the heading “At the Trial” at [26,055].

entry.emph: Applications to be excused from compliance with the necessity to file and serve a witness statement

row.entry: An application by a party for an order that the party not be required to comply with a direction under r 31.4 in respect of any proposed witness or witnesses (whether or not such a direction has been given) may be made without serving notice of motion
You must seek directions from the court if you intend to call expert evidence
Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 29(1)

In determining whether to strike out a defence or dismiss a claim under CPA s 61 , s 57(1)(a) requires the court to have regard to “the just determination of the proceedings” and must be given weight as a fundamental element in the decision making process.
Hans Pet Constructions Pty Ltd v Cassar [2009] NSWCA 230; BC200906750 Rahman v Bimson [2010] NSWSC 338; BC201002471 at [24] per McCallum J

A court is within its rights to refuse an adjournment of the hearing where a party does not appear at the review or file its witness statements, even where the consequence is judgment for the other party.

citefragment.emph: Comet Building Services Pty Ltd v Hy Tec Industries Pty Ltd

row.entry: At the Review, hand the Magistrate a list of witnesses and the time it will take to give their evidence as per
Annexure B to PN Civ 1 of 2011, cl 15.2.

Where parties at the second Call-over are before a Registrar and are unable to take a trial date, the Registrar must refer the matter for a directions hearing before a Magistrate which must be held within 14 days of the second call-over
As to subpoenas and motions, see
Ibid, cll 14, 15

entry.emph: Applications to vacate a trial date

row.entry: Any application to vacate a trial must be made by Notice of Motion and must be made not less than 21 days prior to the allocated trial date, subject to unforeseen circumstances
Ibid, cl 17

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,050] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 177, s 53, 54.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 64, s 65, s 65(2).

entry.emph: Aspect which may require consideration in the course of preparation for trial

row.entry: Do you contemplate calling expert evidence? See
UCPR Pt 31 Div 2rr 31.18–31.45

In the Local Court General Division, the general practice is now in favour of a single expert engaged by the parties or appointed by the Court. Parties must seek directions before calling an expert, and the Court may at any time give directions,
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 29–31
As to the use of single experts, see
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 30
As to joint experts’s reports, see
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 31

A party intending to adduce expert evidence at trial must promptly seek directions from the court, which may give directions (inter alia) as to service and as to the issues upon which expert evidence may be adduced
(This avoids the situation in England under which no expert evidence may be given unless with the permission of the court, it being recommended that this situation should operate in NSW by the
Law Reform Commission on Expert Witnesses (LRC 109))
Directions the court may give may include any of the following:
(a) a direction as to the time for service of experts’ reports,
(b) a direction that expert evidence may not be adduced on a specified issue,
(c) a direction that expert evidence may not be adduced on a specified issue except by leave of the court,
(d) a direction that expert evidence may be adduced on specified issues only,
(e) a direction limiting the number of expert witnesses who may be called to give evidence on a specified issue,
(f) a direction providing for the engagement and instruction of a parties’ single expert in relation to a specified issue,
(g) a direction providing for the appointment and instruction of a court-appointed expert in relation to a specified issue,
(h) a direction requiring experts in relation to the same issue to confer, either before or after preparing experts’ reports in relation to a specified issue,
(i) any other direction that may assist an expert in the exercise of the expert’s functions,
(j) a direction that an expert who has prepared more than one expert’s report in relation to any proceedings is to prepare a single report that reflects his or her evidence in chief.

Where two or more parties call expert witnesses to give opinion evidence about the same issue or similar issues, or indicate to the court an intention to call expert witnesses for that purpose, the court may give directions
Ibid, r 31.35
This rule facilitates “hot tubbing”, that is, calling all the experts at the same time
Ibid, r 31.35(c), (f) and (g)
The court may give a direction that expert witnesses ask questions of each other
Unless the court otherwise orders, an expert witness’s evidence is to be given by way of report
An expert is to provide details of any relevant contingency plans or deferred payment schemes
As to what must be included in an expert’s report, see

You must serve experts’ reports and hospital reports on each other active party in accordance with any court order or practice note, or otherwise not later than 28 days before the date of the hearing.

Otherwise, except by leave of the court, or by consent, the report is not admissible. Leave will not be given unless in exceptional circumstances or the report merely updates an earlier report appropriately served

In the Local Court, it is the responsibility of the party requiring the attendance of an expert for cross-examination to provide and pay for the attendance of the expert, even though the expert involved does not become the party’s witness
If an issue for an expert arises in the proceedings, the court may order that an expert be engaged jointly by the parties affected
As to the procedure for engaging a single expert, see
As to: • Fees for medical expert for compliance with a subpoena;• the mode of service on a medical expert; and• subpoenas requiring the production of medical records, see:
rr 31.31–33 incl
As soon as practicable after engaging an expert witness, whether to give oral evidence or to provide a report, you must provide the expert with a copy of the code of conduct
The expert witness’ code of conduct is contained in:
UCPR Sch 7(see r 31.23)
The new code requires the expert to comply with court directions and to work cooperatively with other expert witnesses
Sch 7 cll (3), (4)

Unless the court otherwise orders, an expert’s report may not be admitted in evidence unless the report contains an acknowledgment by the expert witness, by whom it was prepared, that he or she has read the code of conduct and agrees to be bound by it; and oral evidence may not be received from an expert witness unless the court is satisfied that the expert witness has acknowledged that he or she has read the code of conduct and agrees to be bound by it

Supplementary reports provided to the party by whom the expert has been engaged must be served on all interested parties, or the earlier report is not admissible at the instance of the engaging party or any other party having the same interest as the engaging party
As to the service of reports in professional negligence claims, see
Compulsory conferences between expert witnesses and joint reports arising therefrom are provided for in
As to court-appointed experts, see
A court-appointed expert may apply to the court for directions
As to clarification of a court-appointed expert's report, see
As to certificates of expert evidence, see also
Evidence Act 1995 s 177
Directions hearings may be conducted by online court
PN 6 of 2008
As to tendering experts reports at the hearing, see
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 33
Medical Examinations and Inspection of Property are provided for in

The court may make orders for: (a) the inspection of any property, (b) the taking of samples, (c) the making of any observation of any property, (d) the trying of any experiment on or with any property, (e) the observation of any process.
UCPR Pt 23
Such an order may authorise any person to enter any land, or to do any other things, for the purpose of getting access to the property
UCPR r 23.8
A party applying for preliminary discovery and inspection under Pt 5 can also seek an order for the inspection of property
UCPR r 23.8(5)

If a party is in default under Pt 23, the court may make:(a) an order that the proceedings be dismissed if the defaulting party is the plaintiff; or(b) if the proceedings were commenced by statement of claim and the party in default is a defendant, order that the party’s defence be struck out and that judgment be given accordingly
UCPR r 23.9(1)
As to demonstrations, experiments, inspections and views, see also:
Evidence Act 1995 ss 53 , 54
The court may order that evidence and submissions be received by telephone, video link or other forms of communication
Evidence (Audio and Visual Links) Act 1998; UCPR r 31.3(1)
As to factors relevant to the exercise of the discretion, see:
If you wish to subpoena an interstate witness, issue a subpoena under the:
Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) ss 29, 31; Service and Execution of Process Regulations reg 4 and Form 2
14 days’ notice is necessary unless a shorter period is allowed by the court:
Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) s 30
The court’s general power of amendment is contained in:
CPA s 64

A party may, without leave, amend a statement of claim once within 28 days after it was filed. A party may not make amendments once a date has been fixed for trial unless the court orders otherwise. The defendant may make consequential amendments.
UCPR rr 19.1 , 19.2
• As to amendment of a defence consequent to an amendment of the statement of claim pursuant to r 19.1(1) see:
UCPR r 19.1(2)
• As to amendment of documents generally, including adding or substituting a cause of action arising after the commencement of the proceedngs and mistakes in the name of a party, see:
CPA s 64
• As to amendment of originating process after the expiry of a limitation period, see:
CPA s 65
• The amendment must be limited to correcting the identity of a party or changing the cause of action based on substantially the same facts
CPA s 65(2)
• As to amendment of documents generally, including adding or substituting a cause of action arising after the commencement of the proceedings and mistakes in the name of a party, see:
CPA s 64
• As to amendment of originating process after the expiry of a limitation period, see:
CPA s 65
• The amendment must be limited to correcting the identity of a party or changing the cause of action based on substantially the same facts
CPA s 65(2)

• An order giving leave to amend a document ceases to have effect at the expiration of any time specified in the order, or otherwise at the expiration of 14 days after the date on which the order was made
UCPR r 19.3

• ·Amendments must be made by filing a fresh document amended in accordance with the rules or an order of the court in such a manner as to distinguish the existing material from the amended material and citing the authority for the amendment. (It is no longer possible to make simple amendments by writing the alteration in a document as contemplated by SCR Pt 20 r 20.7).
UCPR r 19.5
As to the dated nature of the decision in Queensland v JL Holdings Pty Ltd (1997) 189 CLR 146; 141 ALR 353; [1997] HCA 1; BC970005 , in the context of multiple amendments, see
• Costs — Unless the court otherwise orders, a party who amends a pleading without leave must after the conclusion of the proceedings pay the costs of and occasioned by the amendment
UCPR r 42.6
UCPR rr 28.1 –28.4

Are there common questions, or rights arising out of related transactions in these or other proceedings before the court which make it appropriate for the several proceedings to be consolidated, or to be tried at the same time, or one immediately after the other, or for one of them to be stayed until the determination of any other of them?
Do you wish to issue a subpoena for the addressee to attend to give evidence or to produce any document or thing or both?
A subpoena must be in the approved form
The approved forms (incorporating subpoena notice) are
Form 25, 26A, 27A

entry.emph: Obtaining documents held by the court

row.entry: If you wish to obtain documents that are held by the court or are part of the court records, issue an appropriate request to the court registry. A subpoena is not appropriate in these circumstances

The date specified in the subpoena must be the date of the trial or any other date permitted by the court. The pre-existing practice of compelling the production of documents otherwise than at hearings is thus maintained.

Service of subpoenas — You must cause the subpoena to be served on the addressee. You must also serve a copy of a subpoena to produce on each other active party as soon as practicable after the subpoena has been served on the addressee
As to the manner in which a subpoena for attendance is to be served in Local Court proceedings, see:
As to the manner in which a subpoena for production is to be served in Local Court proceedings, see:
You must tender conduct money with a subpoena to attend and give evidence. Otherwise the addressee need not attend
Subpoenas must be issued as soon as possible so that documents can be produced and inspected and are available for the proper preparation of the case, including submission to experts
Practice Note Civ 1 of 2011, cl 25.1.

The addressee may comply with a subpoena to produce by either attending with the documents at the relevant time, date and place, or by sending the subpoena and the relevant documents to the appropriate court registrar so that they are received not less than 2 clear days before the date specified
The addressee may, with the consent of the issuing party, produce copies of the relevant documents
As to the inspection of documents or things produced in accordance with r 33.6(4)(b) (production otherwise than on attendance), leave of the court being required, and objection to inspection, see:
Expenses of compliance — The court may order the issuing party to pay the amount of any reasonable loss or expense incurred in complying with the subpoena
As to — fees payable for medical reports to comply with a subpoena,— service of subpoenas on medical experts,— subpoenas requiring production of medical records

Notices to produce — A party may be required to produce documents without the necessity for a subpoena at the hearing, or at any time fixed by the court for return of subpoenas, or, by leave to the court, at any time
The approved form is
Form 24
As to the mode of responding to a notice to produce, see
As to production under notice to produce at trial, see

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,055] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 29.1, r 29.10, r 29.7, r 29.8, r 29.9, r 31.1(2), r 31.10, r 31.4.

row.entry: A trial is “any hearing that is not an interlocutory hearing”
CPA s 3

entry.emph: The mode of adducing evidence in Local Court trials: written statements

row.entry: The relevant UCPR provides that, subject to certain exceptions, “a witness’s evidence at a trial must be given orally before the court”
An exception is that the court may order that all or any of a witness’s evidence at a trial must be given by affidavit, or by witness statement

Thus, the court may direct any party to serve on each other party a written statement of the oral evidence that the party intends to adduce in chief on any question of fact to be decided at any hearing (a witness statement)

The Standard Directions which form part of Local Court PN Civ 1 of 2011 require that each party shall serve upon the court and every party copies of “all of their evidence”, including copies of exhibits to any affidavits at least 4 weeks before the review.
PN Civ 1 of 2011, Annexure CA

Where a party is represented by a solicitor or barrister, a completed copy of the Civil Listing Advice (Annexure B to PN Civ 1) shall be provided to each party’s representative and the court. The time limits for opening addresses, presentation of a party’s case including cross-examination and closing addresses may not be exceeded unless special circumstances exist and leave is granted by the court
PN Civ 1 of 2011, cll 15.5, 15.6

Where a party does not serve evidence in accordance with the SD or any other direcstions made by the court, such evidence may not be admitted, unless the non-complying party satisfies the court that it is in the interest of justice to do so
Standard Directions, Annexure A, cl 5
The requirements for witness statements are also contained in
UCPR r 31.4
In particular, each witness statement must be signed by the intended witness unless the signature of the witness cannot be procured or the court orders otherwise
If an intended witness to whose evidence a witness statement relates does not give evidence, no party may put the statement in evidence at the hearing except by leave of the court

If the party serving the statement calls as a witness at the hearing any person whose witness statement has been served pursuant to a direction under r 31.4(1),(a) that person’s witness statement is to stand as the whole of his or her evidence in chief, so long as that person testifies to the truth of the statement, and (b)except by leave of the court, the party may not adduce from that person any further evidence in chief
A party who fails to comply with a direction under r 31.4 may not adduce evidence to which the direction relates, except by leave of the court
Failure to comply with the court’s directions may result in the statement of claim or cross claim being dismissed, or the defence being struck out with costs.
PN Civ 1 of 2011, Standard Directions , Annexure A, cl 6
The presiding judicial officer may read the affidavit and witness statement prior to the hearing
CPA s 69
The order of evidence and addresses at a trial is set out in

entry.emph: Court directions governing the conduct of the trial

row.entry: At any time before or during the hearing, the court may give:
— directions as to the conduce of any hearing including directions as to the order in which evidence is to be given and addresses made
CPA s 62(1)
— directions as to the order in which questions of fact are to be tried
CPA s 62(2)

Such directions may include:(a) a direction limiting the time that may be taken in the examination, cross-examination or re-examination of a witness,(b) a direction limiting the number of witness (including expert witnesses),(c) a direction limiting the number of documents tendered,(d) a direction limiting the time that may be taken in oral submissions,(e) a direction that all or part of submissions be in writing,(f) a direction limiting the time that may be taken by a party in presenting his or her case;(g) a direction limiting the time that may be taken by the hearing
CPA s 62(3)
The factors which a court may have regard to in deciding whether to make such directions are set out in
CPA s 62(5)

The court may order a solicitor or barrister for a party to give to the party a memorandum stating:(a) the estimated length of the trial, and the solicitor or barrister’s estimated costs; and(b) the estimated costs that, if the party were unsuccessful, would be payable by the party to any other party
CPA s 62(6)
The court may also give or make other directions as to practice and procedure
The consequences for non-compliance being set out in
CPA s 61(3)
For further details, see Directions as to Practice and Procedure generally at‥
The procedure to be followed if a party is absent is set out in
UCPR r 29.7
If any party is absent, the court may proceed with the trial or adjourn it.
If the defendant appears, but the plaintiff does not, the court may dismiss the proceedings

Liquidated claim: If the claim is liquidated, and the plaintiff appears but a defendant does not, the court may, without proceeding to trial, give judgment against that defendant on evidence of:(a) the amount then due to the plaintiff in respect of the cause of action for which the proceedings are commenced, and(b) any payments made or credits accrued since the commencement of the proceedings in reduction of the amount of the plaintiff’s claim or costs

Contested hearings — dismissal of proceedings on plaintiff’s applicationIf you are, or are acting for the plaintiff, you may move for the dismissal of the proceedings to the extent to which they concern:(a) the whole or any part of the plaintiff’s claim for relief; and(b) any cause of action relevant to that claim or part of the claim

Contested hearings — dismissal of proceedings on defendant’s application If at any time after the close of the plaintiff’s case, the defendant is of the view that a judgment for the plaintiff could not be supported, the defendant may apply to the court for an order:(a) for the dismissal of the proceedings, or(b) for the dismissal of the proceedings to the extent that they concern any cause of action relevant to the plaintiff’s claim for relief against the defendant
As to the meaning of ‘capable of supporting’ a judgment, see the cases noted at ‥

The plaintiff may argue, or decline to argue, the question. The court may not make an order for dismissal unless the plaintiff argues the question, and the defendant satisfies the court that on the evidence given a judgment for the plaintiff could not be supported

If the plaintiff declines to argue the question, or if the defendant fails to satisfy the court that on the evidence given a judgment for the plaintiff could not be supported, the defendant(a) may adduce evidence, or further evidence; or(b) may make an application under r 29.10
The court must not entertain the motion for dismissal if fewer than all defendants so move the court
When moving for dismissal, make it clear which rule you are moving under:
Contested hearings — opposite party moves for judgment at close of beginning party’s case (“no case to answer” in the old parlance)

An opposite party has the right to move for judgment at any time after the conclusion of the beginning party’s case in chief on the ground that on the evidence given, a judgment for the beginning party could not be supported
As to the meaning of “beginning party” and “opposite party” see:
As to the meaning of “capable of supporting a judgment” see the cases noted at‥
When making a submission, make it clear that you are moving under this rule rather than r 29.9 .

entry.emph: Contested and uncontested hearings — court’s powers facilitating proof
(1) Power to dispense with the rules in particular cases

row.entry: The court may, by order, dispense with any requirement imposed by the rules of court if satisfied that it is appropriate to do so in the circumstances of the case
CPA s 14
In relation to particular civil proceedings, the court may give directions with respect to any aspect of practice of procedure for which rules of court or practice note do not provide
CPA s 16

At least 7 days before the hearing, a party who intends to tender any plan, photograph or model at the hearing must give the other parties an opportunity to inspect it and to agree to its admission without proof. Otherwise, the non-complying party may not tender the plan, photograph or model in evidence except by leave of the court

The court may: (a) dispense with the rule of evidence for proving any matter that is not bona fide in dispute;(b) dispense with proof of handwriting, documents, the identity of parties or parcels of land or authority;(c) require a party to make admission;(d) if a party refuses to make an admission, order that the costs of proof occasioned by the refusal or neglect be paid by that party
CPA s 70
If you are acting for the plaintiff and have not claimed interest in your originating process, seek leave to amend.
CPA s 64
If you are acting for the defendant in a motor vehicle negligence matter and have not included a claim for contributory negligence, seek leave to amend by the inclusion of such a claim
CPA s 64

level.toc-caption: [26,060] Fresh trials (death, resignation of judicial officer etc)

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,060] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 ss 88, 89.
(NSW) Local Court Act 2007 Sch 1 cl 4, Sch 4 cl 8.

heading.title: Fresh trials (death, resignation of judicial officer etc)

row.entry: If:
(a) proceedings have been listed for trial following the death, resignation or incapacity of a judicial officer; or
(b) an appellate court has made an order for a fresh trial generally; or

(c) a judicial officer has discharged himself or herself; the court may give directions that all or any part of the evidence given at the previous trial be evidence in the fresh trial or give directions that all or any of the witnesses be recalled to give evidence
CPA ss 88 , 89
As to continuation of proceedings after a Magistrates vacation of office in circumstances other than removal (the magistrate may continue to hear the proceedings), see
LCA 2007 Sch 1 cl 4 ; Sch 4 cl 8

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,065] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 20.11(1), r 20.11(4), r 20.11(5), r 20.12(1), r 20.8.

entry.emph: The court’s power to refer proceedings

row.entry: The court may order that proceedings before it for the recovery of damages or other money and ancillary claims be referred for arbitration
CPA s 38(1)

entry.emph: What proceedings may not be referred

row.entry: Proceedings may not be referred for arbitration if(a) no issue in the proceedings is contested, or judgment has been given or entered and not set aside(b) rules of court provide otherwise, or(c) cause is otherwise shown
CPA s 38(3)

Proceedings in which there is an allegation of fraud or proceedings in the Small Claims Division cannot be referred for arbitration, unless the parties consent or the court finds special circumstances
UCPR r 20.8 ; LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 8.5
But note: Part 5 (includes Division 2 — “Arbitration”) does not apply to the SCD (at all)
UCPR Sch 1 Col 3

Referrals for mediation or arbitration are considered at the first or second call-over. Proceedings will only refer proceedings for arbitration if there are no complex issues of fact or law and the hearing is estimated to take 3 hours of less
PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 8.4
A referring court can issue subpoenas for witnesses to attend and to produce documents, and enforce compliance with such orders
CPA s 50
Cf the procedure for the issue of subpoenas in the Local Court generally
LC Civ 1 of 2011, ccl 25–28 incl
CPA s 49
The procedure at an arbitration is as determined by the arbitrator
CPA s 51
Evidence at referred proceedings is received as it would have been before the referring court; such evidence is not required to be recorded; an arbitrator may administer an oath or take an affidavit

entry.emph: The arbitrator’s award and the Registrar’s notice

row.entry: The arbitrator determines the issues in dispute, records his determination and the reasons therefore in writing, and immediately sends the award to the referring court
The arbitrator’s award and reasons are to be in the approved form
As soon as practicable after receiving the award, the registrar must send to each of the parties a copy of the award, with the date of sending set out in the award or in an accompanying notice
The Arbitrator’s Award and Registrar’s Notice is
Form 31
“Date of sending’ means the date of leaving, sending, transmitting or otherwise serving copies of the award

The award is final and conclusive, and is taken to be a judgment of the court:(a) if by consent, on the day on which it is filed in the referring court, or(b) in any other case, at the expiry of 28 days after it is sent to all of the parties
CPA s 40
A person aggrieved by the award may apply to the referring court for a re-hearing, which may be a full rehearing or limited rehearing
CPA s 42(1) and (2)
The award is suspended from the time the application is made until an order for rehearing is made
CPA s 42(3)
An application for rehearing is to be made by notice of motion
The approved form of Notice of Motion for rehearing is
Form 32
The referring court must order a rehearing if the application is made before the award takes effect
CPA s 43(1)
This would seem to imply a discretion to order a rehearing if the application is made thereafter
An order for rehearing may not be made unless the amount claimed or the value of the property involved exceeds the jurisdictional limit of the Small Claims Division
CPA s 43(2)

When there is a request for rehearing, the parties will be advised of a call over date to be held within 28 days of the filing of the request for rehearing, when the court will make appropriate orders
See former PN 1 of 2005 Cl 8.6.2 (does not appear to be covered in LC Civ 1 of 2011)
An order for rehearing need not be made if it appears to the court that the applicant failed to attend a hearing before an arbitrator without good reason
CPA s 43(3)
The referring court may direct that the rehearing be a full or partial rehearing, and in the absence of such a direction the rehearing is to be a full rehearing
CPA s 43(4) and (5)
An order for limited rehearing must specify the relevant issues for determination
CPA s 43(6)
If an order is made for a full rehearing, the award ceases to be effect, and the proceedings are heard and determined as if they had never been referred to an arbitrator
CPA s 44(1)
If an order is made for a limited rehearing the award is suspended until the proceedings are determined
CPA s 44(2)(a)
Following the hearing, the court may reinstate the award with any necessary modifications, and the award then becomes final and conclusive and a judgment of the court
A rehearing may be discontinued by leave or by consent
CPA s 45
As to the arbitrator’s power to award costs, see:
CPA s 54
As to costs on a rehearing, see:
CPA s 46

level.toc-caption: [26,070] Change of Venue in Local Court Proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,070] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Pt 8.

heading.title: Change of Venue in Local Court Proceedings

text.emph: UCPR Pt 8 ; applies to SCD and GD

row.entry: Applications for change of venue under UCPR Pt 8 must be made when the defence is filed of such other time as the court directs
PN LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 10.1
Such applications will not be granted if the other venue is less than 100 km from the originating venue, unless there are exceptional circumstances
The Registrar then lists the matter for either pre-trial review (PTR) of call-over within 6 weeks
If another party objects, they may within 14 days from the date of the sending of the Notice of Listing, file and serve an affidavit in response
A precedent for such an affidavit is set out at
Unless the court otherwise orders, the issue is determined in chambers 14 days after the notice of listing was sent; if changed, cancels PTR of call-over and obtains new one at fresh venue
If not changed, Registrar informs active parties that the PTR or call-over date is confirmed
The maximum costs are $150 SCD; $300 GD

level.toc-caption: [26,080] Transfer of proceedings between higher and lower courts

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,080] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

heading.title: Transfer of proceedings between higher and lower courts

entry.emph: Transfer of proceedings from the Local Court (the lower court) to the Supreme Court or the District Court (the higher court)

row.entry: The Supreme Court may of its own motion or on application by a party order that proceedings be transferred from the Local Court to the Supreme Court
CPA s 140(1)
The District Court may of its own motion or on application by a party order that proceedings be transferred from the Local Court to the District Court
CPA s 140(2)
Proceedings in a Local Court are not to be transferred to a higher court unless the higher Court is satisfied that there is sufficient reason for hearing the proceedings in the higher Court
CPA s 140(4)
The transfer order takes effect when it is made
CPA s 141
The higher court may order a stay of the lower court proceedings
CPA s 142
As to proceedings after the transfer, see:
CPA s 143

entry.emph: Transfer of proceedings from a higher court (the Supreme Court or District Court) to the Local Court

row.entry: If the Supreme Court is satisfied that the proceedings before it could properly have been commenced in the Local Court, and that any cross-claim in the proceedings could properly have been brought as a cross-claim in the Local Court, it may order that the proceedings be transferred to the Local Court
CPA s 146(1)
Similarly, in relation to the District Court as regards transfer of proceedings to the Local Court
CPA s 146(2)
The higher court must have regard to the current limits of the lower court’s jurisdiction when the proceedings were commenced or the cross-claim brought in the higher court
CPA s 146(3)
A transfer order takes effect when it is made
CPA s 147
As to proceedings after transfer, see:
CPA s 148

The lower court has and may exercise all of the higher court’s jurisdiction in relation to any proceedings to which a transfer order relates. This includes jurisdiction to determine any questions that arise in the proceedings
CPA s 149

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,085] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 43.10, r 43.11, r 43.2, r 43.3, r 43.4, r 43.5, r 43.6, r 43.7, r 43.8, r 43.9.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 Pt 6.

row.entry: If you are, or are acting for, a person who is being sued or expects to be sued as stakeholder, in any court by 2 or more claimants, you may seek relief by way of interpleader

You may apply for relief by:(a) filing a notice of motion, if proceedings have been commenced against you in respect of disputed property; or(b) commencing fresh proceedings, if proceedings have not been commenced against you.

Your application must be accompanied by an affidavit which states:(a) that you have no interest in the subject-matter in dispute other than for charges or costs;(b) that you are not acting in collusion with any claimant; and(c) that you are willing to pay or transfer the subject-matter in dispute into court or, if the court so requires, to give security to the value of the subject-matter

Service: If you seek relief by way of notice of motion, you must personally serve the notice of motion:(a) on each party to the proceedings who claim an interest in the disputed property, and(b) on each claimant who is not a party to the proceedings
If the Sheriff intends to take possession of any disputed property undera writ of execution, a claimant may give notice of his or her claim to the Sheriff
The approved form is
Form 75

If a claimant does not give a notice of claim within a reasonable time after becoming aware that the Sheriff has or intends to take possession, the Sheriff may apply to restrain the claimant from commencing or continuing proceedings against the Sheriff
Notice of such an application must be personally served on the claimant

When a claim is received, the Sheriff is to give a copy of the notice to the judgment creditor. If the judgment creditor admits the claim, the Sheriff must withdraw from possession of the disputed property
On the application of the Sheriff, the court may make an order restraining the claimant from commencing or continuing proceedings against the Sheriff

If the execution creditor does not, within 4 days after service of the notice, serve a notice of admission on the Sheriff, and the claim is not withdrawn, the Sheriff may apply by notice of motion to the court in which the writ of execution was issued seeking relief by way of interpleader
The court may dismiss the application unless notified that the applicant claims no interest in the disputed property and is not in collusion with any claimant
Service: Personal service must be effected:(a) on each party to the proceedings who claims an interest in the disputed property, and(b) on each claimant who is not a party to the proceedings

Note: that in the Local Court (and District) Courts, there is no longer any provision for a claimant to pay to the Sheriff an amount equal to the value of the property or security therefore (whereupon the property was thereupon released from execution), compelling the Sheriff to then apply for interpleader relief under the now repealed s 65 of the Local Courts (Civil Claims) Act 1970.

entry.emph: The court’s powers generally when dealing with interpleader proceedings

row.entry: The court may:(a) order that a claimant be added as a defendant in addition to or in substitution for the defendant, or order that the proceedings be stayed or dismissed;(b) order that other proceedings in which the applicant is sued for or in respect of the disputed property be stayed;(c) order the applicant to pay or transfer all of the disputed property into court;(d) make orders for the sale of any or all of the disputed property;(e) summarily determine questions of fact or law;(f) make orders for the settlement and trial of questions
If a claimant does not appear, it may order that the claimant be barred from prosecuting the claim against the applicant
If on an application for interpleader relief, multiple proceedings are pending, the court may make an order in any two or more of the proceedings
The provisions of CPA Pt 6 (dealing with Case Management) apply

level.toc-caption: [26,090] Judgments and orders by the court

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,090] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 90, s 93(1), s 93(2).
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.4, r 36.1, r 36.11.

heading.title: Judgments and orders by the court

row.entry: The court may give such judgment or order as the nature of the case requires, whether or not a claim for relief extending to that judgment or order is included in any originating process or notice of motion
CPA s 90 , UCPR r 36.1
As to entry of judgments and orders, see
As to the judicial obligation to provide reasons for decision, see
In cases involving the assessment of damages or the value of goods under Pt 30, evidence of facts must be given by affidavit
UCPR r 31.4

In proceedings for the detention of goods, the court may (whether or not theirvalue has yet been assessed) give judgment:(a) for their delivery to the plaintiff; or(b) for payment to the plaintiff of an amount equivalent to their assessed value; or(c) for their delivery to the plaintiff or for payment to the plaintiff of their assessed value, at the defendant’s option;and in addition may also give judgment for payment to the plaintiff of damages for their detention
CPA s 93(1)
As to ancillary orders which may be appropriate in each of the above circumstances, see:
As to the circumstances in which each of the above orders may be appropriate, see:
Damages for the value of the goods, and damages for their detention should be assessed separately

p.text: Note: See also “Execution upon a judgment for delivery of goods” at [26,205.25] .

row.entry: As to default judgment of claim for detention of goods, and what the relevant affidavits in support must state, see
UCPR r 16.5
The relevant form for Notice of motion — default judgment for detention of goods is
Form 37
As to default judgment on debt or liquidated claim, and what the relevant affidavits in support must state, see
UCPR r 16.6
The relevant form for Notice of Motion — default judgment for liquidated claim is
Form 38
As to default judgment on claim for unliquidated damages, and what the relevant affidavits in support must state, see
UCPR r 16.7
The relevant form for Notice of Motion — default judgment for unliquidated damages is
Form 39

level.toc-caption: [26,100] Assessment of damages and value of goods

heading.title: Assessment of damages and value of goods

row.entry: Where judgment has been given against a party for damages to be assessed, or for the value of goods, evidence of the assessment of damages or the value of goods must be given by affidavit if that is the only matter in dispute (barring interest and costs)
Transitional: An order for judgment is taken to be a judgment if the order was given before the CPA commenced on 15 August 2005
Civil Procedure Regulation 2005 cl 17

level.toc-caption: [26,105] Ancillary order — interest, and witness expenses

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,105] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 100, s 101(7).
(NSW) Legal Profession Act 2004 [375,140].

heading.title: Ancillary order — interest, and witness expenses

row.entry: In the case of a liquidated claim, a claim for interest up to judgment must specify the period or periods and the rate or rates at which interest is claimed
If no rate of interest is thus specified, the rate of interest is as prescribed by
CPA s 100 ; UCPR Sch 5
Rates of pre-judgment interest for relevant periods are specified in
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 37.1
The prescribed rate of interest is that prescribed by the UCPR
CPA s 101(7) , r 36.7(1); UCPR Sch 5
The relevant rates are set out behind the Local Court Guide Card under the designation ‘Costs’ at :
A Local Court may not order the payment of interest up to judgment in proceedings where the amount claimed is less than $1000
As to witnesses expenses, see:
Legal Profession Act 2004 s 329(1)(f) at [375,140]
(No regulation has yet been made under the section promulgating scales for witness expenses)

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,110] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 3(1), s 60, s 98, s 98(2), s 98(5), s 99.

row.entry: “Costs” means costs payable in or in relation to the proceedings, and includes fees, disbursements, expenses and remuneration
CPA s 3(1)

There are two categories of costs — the ordinary basis and the indemnity basis. “Ordinary basis”, in relation to the assessment of legal costs that a court has ordered to be paid, means the basis of assessing costs set out in s 364(1) and (2) of the Legal Profession Act 2004. The term “party/party” costs therefore properly refers to the identification of persons between whom an assessment under the LPA 2004 is taking place. It should not be confused with the “ordinary basis” as the lower basis of quantifying costs.
CPA s 3(1)

When the court makes an order for indemnity costs, (with the exception of costs ordered to be paid from trusts and other fiduciary situations), all costs (other than those that appear to have been unreasonably incurred or appear to be of an unreasonable amount) are to be allowed
UCPR 42.5
Costs payable to a person under an order of the court are generally assessed on the ordinary basis
