Costs are in the discretion of the court, and the court has full power to determine by whom, to whom and to what extent costs are to be paid. The court may order that costs be awarded on an ordinary basis or on an indemnity basis
CPA s 98

The court is required to implement its practices and procedures so that the proceedings are resolved on the basis that the cost to the parties is proportionate to the complexity of the subject matter in dispute
CPA s 60

A party is not entitled to receive costs from any other party, otherwise than pursuant to an order (Where each party is to bear its own costs, the appropriate order is therefore “no order as to costs”)
CPA s 98(2)

Subject to certain exceptions, costs may not be awarded against a person who is a non-party. This is subject to r 42.27 (which deals with costs where there is a failure to comply with an order to attend court)
As to costs against a married woman, see:
CPA s 98(5)

After giving the legal practitioner a reasonable opportunity to be heard, costs can be imposed against a legal practitioner where costs have been incurred by the serious neglect, serious incompetence or serious misconduct of a legal practitioner, or improperly, or without reasonable cause, in circumstances for which a legal practitioner is responsible. Note: The Local Court now has this statutory power.
CPA s 99
Costs can also be awarded against a legal practitioner under
Unless the court orders otherwise, interlocutory costs and reserved costs are not payable until the conclusion of the proceedings
As to costs and:• offers of compromise, see:• offers to contribute• security for costs• proving a fact or the authenticity of a document that has been in dispute

As to Smyth orders (orders that a party’s legal representative serve on the party a notice of the best and worst outcomes which a party may gain or suffer if the proceedings are contested to finality), see:

entry.emph: Scales of costs under the Legal Profession Regulation 2005

row.entry: These may be found behind the Local Court Guide Card under the designation ‘Costs’ at

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,115] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

entry.emph: Amount claimed in the General Division $20,000 or less — maximum costs orders

row.entry: The costs orders the court may make and the foundations therefore, depending on who is successful, are specified in
PN Civ 1 of 2011, cl 36

entry.emph: Cost at the end of a trial in the Local Court

row.entry: The relevant principles are encapsulated in
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 34
Parties should have available a summary of the fair and reasonable costs that will be sought and evidence of time spent
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 34.3
The court will not engage in a taxing exercise, but will consider whether the time spent on the case was reasonable in the circumstances
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 34.4
Guideline amounts are speficied in
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 35
Costs will be increased in accordance with the CPI
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 35.5
PN Civ 1 of 2011 does not affaect the court’s power to award costs ona different basis or to make costs orders on an indemnity basis
LC Civ 1 of 2011, cl 35.6
Bearing this in mind, the following provisions of a more general nature are also included:

A person who has paid or is liable to pay, or who is entitled to receive or who has received, costs as a result of an order for the payment of an unspecified amount of costs made by a court, may apply to the Manager, Costs Assessment for an assessment of the whole or any part of those costs:
Legal Profession Act 2004 (LPA) s 353(1)
As to the procedure to be followed before application where the application is to be made by the person to whom the costs are payable:
LP Reg 2005 cl 125(1)
As to the procedure to be followed before application where the application is to be made by the person liable to pay the costs:
LP Reg 2005 cl 125(2)
A court may direct the Manager, Costs Assessment to refer for assessment costs payable as a result of an order made by the court or tribunal. This is taken to be an application for assessment:
LPA s 353(2)
An application for party/party costs is to be made in the approved form and accompanied by the prescribed fee
LPA s 354 ; LP Reg cl 124
As to the approved form see:

The application must:• authorize a cost assessor to have access to and inspect all relevant documents;• contain a statement that there is no reasonable prospect of settlement of the matter by mediation
A copy of the application is to be sent by the Manager, Costs Assessment to the relevant parties
The Manager, Costs Assessment, refers each application for a costs assessment to a costs assessor:
LPA s 357

In conducting an assessment of legal costs payable as a result of an order of the court, the costs assessor considers: • whether or not it was reasonable to carry out the work to which the costs relate, and • whether or not the work was carried out in a reasonable manner, and • what is a fair and reasonable amount of costs for the work
LPA s 363(1)

In considering what is a fair and reasonable amount of legal costs, a costs assessor may have regard to any or all of the following matters: • the skill, labour and responsibility displayed on the part of the Australian legal practitioner or Australian-registered foreign lawyer responsible for the matter, • the complexity, novelty or difficulty of the matter, • the quality of the work done and whether the level of expertise was appropriate to the nature of the work done, • the place where and circumstances in which the legal services were provided, • the time within which the work was required to be done, • the outcome of the matter:
LPA s 363(2)
Rules of court An assessment must be made in accordance with the operation of the rules of the court that made the order for costs and any relevant regulations:
LPA s 363(3)

Indemnity basis If the court has ordered that costs are to be assessed on an indemnity basis, the costs assessor must assess the costs on that basis, having regard to any relevant rules of the court and relevant regulations:
LPA s 363(4)

Costs agreement A costs assessor may obtain a copy of, and may have regard to, a costs agreement. However, he or she must not apply the terms of a costs agreement for the purposes of determining appropriate fair and reasonable costs when assessing costs payable as a result of an order by a court.
Court may determine amount of costs The Court may itself determine the amount of costs payable or that the amount of the costs be determined on an indemnity basis:
LPA s 366

entry.emph: Determination of costs assessments for party/party costs

row.entry: A costs assessor is to determine an application for an assessment of costs payable as a result of an order made by a court by making a determination of the fair and reasonable amount of those costs:
LPA s 367A
The costs assessor issues to each party and the Manager, Costs Assessment, a certificate setting out the determination:
LPA s 368(1)

Outstanding costs in certificate may be sued for In the case of an amount of costs that has been paid, the amount (if any) by which the amount paid exceeds the amount specified in any such certificate may be recovered as a debt in a court of competent jurisdiction:
LPA s 368(4)

In the case of an amount of costs that has not been paid, the certificate may be filed in the office or registry of a court having jurisdiction to order the payment of that amount of money, and with no further action, is taken to be a judgment of that court for the amount of unpaid costs, and the rate of any interest payable in respect of that amount of costs is the rate of interest in the court in which the certificate is filed:
LPA s 368(4)

entry.emph: Recovery of costs of costs assessment

row.entry: As to the recovery of the costs of the costs assessment, see
LPA s 369 ; LP Reg cl 126
A costs assessor’s certificate as to determination (under s 368) or as to recovery of costs assessment (under s 369) must be accompanied by reasons
LPA s 370
A costs assessor’s determination is final
LPA s 372
However, as to applications for review of a costs assessor’s determination, see:
LPA s 373 ff
As to appeals on a matter of law, see
LPA s 380 ff

level.toc-caption: [26,200] Appropriation of payments towards the judgment debt

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,200] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 136.

heading.title: Appropriation of payments towards the judgment debt

row.entry: Unless the court otherwise orders, any payment made on account of a judgment debt is to be appropriated firstly towards s 101 interest, and only then towards the balance of the judgment debt
CPA s 136

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,205] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

row.entry: A judgment in any action at law does not of itself bind or affect the land
CPA s 112(3)
A judgment or order of the court may not be enforced until is has been entered
CPA s 133
As to the registrar’s obligation to seal a document provided by an applicant setting out the terms of a judgment or order which then becomes a sealed copy, see
An application for a writ of execution or a garnishee order may not be made, except by leave of the court, if 12 years has elapsed since the judgment was given
In the Local Court, a judgment debt may be enforced by:(a) a writ for the levy of property;(b) a garnishee order
CPA s 106(1)
The Local Court has no jurisdiction in respect of charging orders or claims for possession of land
CPA s 106(1)(c) ; CPA s 20 ; DCA s 133

level.toc-caption: [26,205.10] Time to pay and payment by instalments

heading.title: Time to pay and payment by instalments

row.entry: The judgment creditor and the judgment debtor may make an agreement to pay a debt by instalments
A judgment debtor may apply to the court for an instalment order
The approved form is
Form 46
or, in relation to a Corporation
Form 47
As to a commercial agent’s right to commence and carry on these proceedings, see
The Notice of Motion must be supported by an affidavit as to the judgment debtor’s financial circumstances

Application may be made not only to the court in which judgment was entered, but also, in the case of a judgment entered in a Local Court, to any other Local Court by which an examination is being conducted under r 38.5(2)
It may be dealt with by the registrar or determined by a court under r 37.4
Where the Registrar deals with the application it is determined in the absence of the public. He or she may refuse or make an instalment order

As soon as practicable after making an instalment order, the Registrar:(a) must give notice of the order to the judgement creditor and the judgment debtor, and(b) must also give a copy of the judgment debtor’s affidavit as to financial circumstances to the judgment creditor
The approved form of Registrar’s notice of refusal to make an instalment order is
Form 49
Either party may file an objection at any time within 14 days after the order is made
As to instalment orders which become the subject of a garnishee order, see:
CPA ss 119 , 121
The approved Form of Notice of Motion objecting to an instalment order is
Form 50
The approved form of Registrar’s notice of order for payment by instalments is
Form 48
The court determines the application for instalment order under r 37.2(3)(b), or the objection under r 37.3
Execution stayed In the meantime, execution of the judgment is stayed
Improvement in judgment debtor’s financial circumstancesAn instalment order may be varied or rescinded if the judgment’s debtor’s financial situation improves
An instalment order ceases to have effect if the judgment debtor fails to comply with the order

An application for a writ of execution in relation to a judgment debt that has been the subject of an instalment order that has ceased to have effect may not be granted unless the judgment creditor has filed an affidavit as to the judgment debtor’s failure to comply with the order
An order for examination may not be made, except by leave of the court, if 12 years have elapsed since the judgment was given
As to a commercial agent’s right to commence and carry on these proceedings, see

The court may make an order requiring a person bound by a judgment or order:(a) to attend the court to be orally examined as to any material question; or(b) to produce any document or thing that is in his or her possession and that relates to a material question
CPA s 108(1)
As to “material question”, see:
CPA s 108(5)
As to corporations, see:
CPA s 108(2)
Before seeking an order for examination, a judgment creditor must, subject to the rules, issue an examination notice
An examination notice requires the person bound by the judgment or order to provide answers to specific questions, and to produce specified documents in relation to material questions
It must specify the period (not less than 28 days) within which its requirements must be complied with
The approved form of Examination Notice is
Form 51 (Individual), Form 52 (corporation)

An application for an order for examination must be supported by an affidavit, to the effect that (inter alia) the judgment debtor has failed to provide any or sufficient answers to the questions in the examination notice or to produce any or sufficient documents
The approved form of Notice of Motion for Examination Order is
Form 53
In the Local (and District) Court, an order for examination may only be made where the judgment debtor has failed to comply with the examination notice
The approved form of Examination order is
Form 54
An order for examination must be served on the person bound at least 14 days before the day on which he or she is required to attend for examination

There can be no further order for examination of the same person within 3 months after the order is made in relation to the same judgment or order r 38.3(4) A person may refuse to produce a document or thing in response to an order for examination if he or she could lawfully refuse to produce that document or thing in answer to a subpoena

If the court is satisfied that the person neither resides nor carries on business within 30 km of the venue where the judgment or order was entered, the examination is to be conducted at the premises of the court nearest to where the person resides or carries on business, as the court may determine
The examination is to be conducted by the judgment creditor unless the court orders otherwise

A registrar or court may conduct an examination on behalf of the judgment creditor only where:(a) the person attends for examination following his or her arrest pursuant to a s 97 arrest warrant as a consequence of the person’s failure to comply with the order for examination (see below);(b) the person attends for examination otherwise than at the time specified in the order; or(c) the court is satisfied that for any other reason the circumstances so warrant (eg the requirement to attend at remote locations
The Form of Registrar’s Examination for an individual is
Form 55
Where the judgment debtor fails to attend, an arrest warrant may be issued or revoked, either on the court’s own motion or the application of the judgment creditor
CPA s 97 , r 38.6
The approved form of Notice of Motion for Arrest Warrant is
Form 57
The warrant may be issued not earlier than 14 days, nor later than three months, after the court has notified the judgment debtor that the failure to attend may result in the person’s arrest

Where the person bound by the judgment order is a corporation, an examination notice may be addressed to, and an order for examination may be made against, an officer or former officer of the corporation
The Form of Registrar’s Examination in the case of a Corporation is
Form 56

level.toc-caption: [26,205.20] Writs for the levy of property

heading.title: Writs for the levy of property

row.entry: Leave of the court — Certain writs require the leave of the court before they can be issued, eg. if there has been a change in the person entitled or liable to execution under the judgment
If leave is required it may be applied for in the notice of motion for the writ of execution
The evidence which is required in support of the motion for leave is set out in

An application for a writ of execution is to be made by way of notice of motion which, unless the court order otherwise,(a) may be dealt with in the absence of the parties, and(b) need not be served on the judgment debtor
The application must indicate the extent (if any) to which the judgment debt has been satisfied under any writ of execution or garnishee order
As to a commercial agent’s right to commence and carry on these proceedings, see
An applicant for a writ of execution must file an affidavit (sworn not more than 14 days beforehand). The contents of such an affidavit in the case of a writ for the levy of property, are set out at

In the case of an application for a writ for the levy of property, there must be included:(a) the amount payable under the judgment together with any costs and interest payable; and(b) the address or addresses at which property belonging to the debtor may be located

entry.emph: Instalment order ceased to have effect

row.entry: An application in relation to a judgment debt that has been the subject of an instalment order that has ceased to have effect may not be granted unless the judgment creditor has filed an affidavit as to the judgment debtor’s failure to comply with the order
The approved form of Notice of Motion for a writ for the delivery of goods is
Form 63
The approved form of Notice of Motion of writ for the levy of property is
Form 65

entry.emph: What may be seized and sold

row.entry: As to what may be seized and sold in execution by the Sheriff under a writ for the levy of property, see:
CPA s 106(2)

In brief, they comprise:(a) any goods of or to which the judgment debtor is or may be possessed or entitled or which the judgment debtor may, at law or in equity, assign or dispose of;(b) money;(c) cheques, bills of exchange, promissory notes, bonds, specialties or other securities for money;(d) land;(e) choses in action or registrable interests
As to goods the subject of a conditional bill of sale and securities, see:
CPA ss 110 , 111

entry.emph: What may not be seized and sold?

row.entry: The power thus conferred on the Sheriff may not be exercised in relation to: (a) any clothing, or (b) any bedroom or kitchen furniture, or(c) any tools of trade (including vehicles, plant, equipment and reference books) not exceeding in aggregate $2000, if the clothing, furniture or ools are used by the judgment debtor or by any member of his or her family

After seizing a judgment debtor’s goods pursuant to a writ of delivery or writ for the levy of property, the Sheriff may appoint the judgment debtor or some other person as custodian of the goods pending their delivery or sale
CPA s 132(1)
The person so appointed must not sell, damage or otherwise deal with the property, otherwise than with leave of the court of the Sheriff’s written consent
CPA s 132(2)
The Sheriff’s obligations in relation to the sale of property seized for sale are further set out in
and, as regards goods, specifically in
A writ of execution may not be executed on Christmas Day or Good Friday
A writ of execution has effect for 12 months, but subject to the rules, may be renewed

However, subject to CPA s 135 (which empowers the court to give direction with respect to the enforcement of its judgments and orders) the expiry of a writ for the levy of property does not affect any agreement for the sale or other transaction entered into under the authority of the writ before that expiry.
CPA s 116
It would also seem that if the execution by sale has commenced within 12 months, the sale may be completed after the expiry of that period
Jordan v Binckes (1849) 18 LJ (NS) 277; Greenshields v Harris (1842) 9 M & W 774; 152 ER 328
Transitional: A writ of execution in existence when the CPA commenced on 15 August 2005 will operate for 12 months from the date on which it was issued
Civil Procedure Regulation 2005 (CPR) Cl 14

entry.emph: Property/land bound from time writ delivered to Sheriff

row.entry: A writ of execution against goods binds the property in the goods as from the time the writ is delivered to the Sheriff (cf Sale of Goods Act 1923 s 29)
CPA s 109

A writ of execution against land binds the land as from the time the writ is delivered to the Sheriff in the same way as a writ of execution against goods binds the property in the goods (cf Judgment Creditors Remedies Act 1901 s 13)
CPA s 112(1)

entry.emph: Bona fide purchasers for value protected

row.entry: In each case, a writ of execution does not affect the title acquired by a person in good faith and for valuable consideration, unless, when the person acquires title, he or she has notice that such a writ has been delivered to the Sheriff and remains unexecuted
A writ for possession of land requires the leave of the court
The approved form of writ Notice of Motion of writ for possession of land is
Form 59
As to how the land must be described, see
r 4.7A

Land must not be sold before any other property unless:(a) the judgment debtor so requests, or(b) the Sheriff is satisfied that the land should be sold before the other property in order to minimise hardship to the judgment debtor or some other person

The Sheriff must not enter upon and sell land if the amount outstanding under the judgment is less than the jurisdictional limit of a Local Court when sitting in its Small Claims Division (presently $10,000)
CPA s 106(5)
To commence enforcement of a writ against land, the creditor must register a copy of the writ for the levy of property under
Real Property Act 1900 (‘the RP Act’) s 105 at [405,105]
This may be done at any time after the issue of the writ of levy against property, notwithstanding any action that the Sheriff is taking to sell personal property.
“An Introduction to CPA and UCPR 2005 ” by Atkinson and Olischlager, August 2005

During the period of six months after the writ is registered or the expiration of the writ (whichever first occurs), the land may not be sold or mortgaged by the judgment debtor otherwise than with the judgment creditor’s consent.
CPA s 113
The specifics of this consent are set out in
CPA s 113(3)

entry.emph: Notice of intention to sell land

row.entry: In order to proceed beyond registration to the sale of land, the judgment creditor must file an affidavit verifying that: (a) the writ has been registered against the land under s 105 of the RP Act, or in the General Register of Deeds under s 186 of the Conveyancing Act, and (b) the Sheriff has provided advice to the effect that the Sheriff has not obtained satisfaction against the judgment debtor’s goods

The judgment creditor must also file and serve on the judgment debtor a notice of intention to sell the land. The notice advises the judgment debtor that:(a) the writ has been registered;(b) the judgment creditor intends that the land be sold after 4 weeks;(c) the judgment debtor is entitled to apply for an instalment order under
As to the procedural steps which must be satisfied before the sale may take place, see:
In particular, the Sheriff must be provided with details of the value of the property
The sale must be publicly advertised, and the Sheriff must be provided with proof of service of the notice of sale and particulars of each advertisement
As to the formalities consequent upon the sale, see:

On request by the judgment creditor, the Sheriff must return the writ to the court in which it was issued, together with a notice indicating: (a) what action, if any, has been taken in execution of the writ, and (b) whether or not the writ has been satisfied
It is not be necessary for the writ to be returned in most proceedings. However, it is necessary to establish an act of bankruptcy under s 40(1)(d) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 (Cth).”
Atkinson & Olischlager, “An Introduction...” p 56

level.toc-caption: [26,205.25] Execution upon a judgment for delivery of goods

heading.title: Execution upon a judgment for delivery of goods

row.entry: The application is to be made by notice of motion

The application in support (which must be sworn not more than 14 days beforehand): (a) must state which goods have, and which have not, been delivered to the plaintiff since the judgment, and (b) must give particulars of any payments, if any, the defendant has made to the plaintiff in respect of the goods since the judgment, and (c) must state the address at which the goods are alleged to be located
The approved from of Notice of Motion for a writ for the delivery of goods is
Form 63
The approved from of writ for the levy of property is
Form 65

p.text: Note: See also “Judgment for detention of goods” at [26,075] .

row.entry: For garnishee order generally, see:
An application for a garnishee order is to be made by notice of motion
The application must indicate the extent (if any) to which the judgment debt has been satisfied under any writ of execution or garnishee order issued by the court
Unless the court orders otherwise, the notice of motion may be dealt with in the absence of the parties, and need not be served on the judgment debtor or the proposed garnishee
As to a commercial agent’s right to commence and carry on these proceedings, see
The approved form of Notice of Motion for garnishee order is
Form 69

The application must be supported by an affidavit (sworn not more than 14 days before filing):(a) identifying the garnishee;(b) stating the amount payable under the judgment(c) stating if the judgment was entered as a result of a cost assessor’s certificate, plus
(d) if the application is in relation to an instalment order that has ceased to have effect, an affidavit that the judgment debtor has failed to complywith an instalment order
The approved form of garnishee order for debts is
The approved form of garnishee order for wages and salary is
Form 71
The court may refuse to make a garnishee order, for example if the amount involved is too small
The order takes effect when it is served on the garnishee

A garnishee order operates to attach, to the extent of the amount outstanding under the judgment, all debts that are due or accruing from the garnishee to the judgment debtor at the time of service of the order
CPA s 117(1)
Any amount standing to the credit of the judgment debtor in a financial institution is taken to be a debt owed to the judgment debtor by that institution
CPA s 117(2)

entry.emph: Time within which payment to be made

row.entry: Payment of the attached debt must be made within 14 days after the date on which the order is served on the garnishee; or if the order attaches a debt falling due after that date, within 14 days of the date on which the debt falls due
CPA s 118

If the garnishee order attaches a debt due to the judgment debtor more than 28 days after service, the garnishee must within that period, cause notice of that fact to be served on the judgment creditor

The garnishee order operates to attach, to the extent of the amount outstanding under the judgment: (a) any wage or salary that is payable to the judgment debtor by the garnishee, or (b) if the judgment debtor becomes the subject of an instalment order, such amounts from the judgment debtor’s wage or salary as are equivalent to the instalments under the instalment order
CPA s 119(1)
The order takes effect as from the time the garnishee order is served on the garnishee and ceases to have effect when the judgment debt is satisfied
CPA s 119(2) and (3)
The order binds the Crown in respect of NSW
CPA s 119(4)
but not the Commonwealth
Public Service Act 1999 (Cth) s 75
Payment must be made by the garnishee within 14 days after the date when the wage or salary falls due
CPA s 120
As to concurrent garnishee orders, see:
CPA s 121
The maximum amount that may be deducted from wages or salary must not reduce the net weekly amount received by the judgment debtor to less than 80% of the standard workers compensation weekly benefit
CPA s 122(1)
As to the meaning of “standard workers compensation benefit”, see:
CPA s 122(2)
The garnishee must pay the money directly to the judgment creditor
CPA s 123
The garnishee is entitled to retain administrative expenses of $13.00 from each payment (unless the garnishee order is in relation to a judgment debt the subject of an instalment order
CPA s 123 ; r 39.42; UCPR Sch 3
An amount retained by the garnishee for administrative expenses does not operate to reduce the judgment debt
CPA s 123(5)

A garnishee who believes that: (a) no debt from the garnishee to the judgment debtor was due or accruing when the garnishee order was served on the garnishee, or (b) no wage or salary will become payable by the garnishee to the judgment debtor during the period for which the order will be in force, may serve on the judgment creditor a statement to that effect, verified by affidavit, being a statement that contains a summary of the grounds on which the garnishee’s belief is based
The prescribed form of garnishee's statement that no debt due or accruing or no wage or salary payable is
Form 72

entry.emph: Claims by third parties to the debt attached

row.entry: If the garnishee asserts a claim or claims by third parties to the debt, wage or salary attached, the matter may be determined by the court
On the application of a judgment creditor who considers that the garnishee order has not been complied with, the court may hear and determine the issue
CPA s 124
The judgment creditor must forthwith notify the judgment debtor and the garnishee of the payment of excess mounts, and on demand repay the excess to the judgment debtor
CPA s 125
As to funds in court (which applies also in the Local Court with the exception of “Stop orders” — r 41.16), see:
UCPR Pt 41

level.toc-caption: [26,210] Enforcement of judgments obtained in law outside the state

heading.title: Enforcement of judgments obtained in law outside the state

row.entry: Interstate judgments may be registered in the court of most limited jurisdiction “in or by which relief as given by the judgment could have been given”. All that is necessary is to lodge a sealed copy of a judgment or a facsimile thereof. If a fax is lodged, a sealed copy of the judgment must be lodged within 7 days
Service and Execution of Process Act 1992 (Cth) s 105
The court in which the judgment has been registered may on application by a person against whom the judgment has been given, grant a stay for a specified period
Service and Execution of Process Act (Cth) s 106
Interest is payable at the same rate or rates and in respect of the same period or periods as are applicable in the court which gave the judgment
Service and Execution of Process Act (Cth) s 108

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,215] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 91.

level.toc-caption: [26,215.5] Discontinuance, withdrawal and dismissal, and setting aside of originating process

heading.title: Discontinuance, withdrawal and dismissal, and setting aside of originating process

row.entry: The plaintiff may discontinue proceedings either as to all claims for relief so far as they concern a particular defendant or any part of a claim for relief by consent of parties who have been served (if the party has not been served, the plaintiff should file an affidavit to that effect) or by leave
If the claim or the defence is conducted with lack of due despatch, the court may dismiss the claim or strike out the defence

The Local Court may also dismiss proceedings in which a statement of claim has been filed if:(a) a defence or cross-claim is not filed; or(b) a default judgment is not entered; or(c) the proceedings are not otherwise disposed of within 9 months after the filing of the statement of claim
Such an order may be made without notice to the plaintiff or other party but not if there are any notices of motion or other applications in the proceedings that are yet to be determined
As to the costs of proceedings that are discontinued or dismissed, see:
The court may order a stay of further proceedings to secure the costs of the proceedings dismissed
As to the effect of dismissal, see:
CPA s 91
Withdrawal
• of appearance may be made by leave

• of matter in a defence or subsequent pleading may be made by filing a notice of withdrawal at any time stating the extent thereof, but if the matter is an admission or something that operates for the benefit of another party, only with the consent of the other party or by leave of the court:

level.toc-caption: [26,220.5] Judgment irregular, unlawful or against good faith

heading.title: Judgment irregular, unlawful or against good faith

row.entry: A judgment or order of the court may, on sufficient cause being shown, be set aside if the judgment was given or entered, or if the order was made, irregularly, illegally or against good faith
A judgment or order may also be set aside by consent
The court may also set aside or vary a judgment or order if notice of motion for the setting aside or variation is filed before entry of the judgment order

The court may also set aside or vary a judgment or order even after it has been entered if:(a) the judgment or order is by default (Pt 16),(b) the judgment or order was made or given in the absence of a party, whether or not the absent party had notice of the relevant hearing
In essence, the applicant must explain the reasons for the default, and satisfy the court that he or she has a bona fide defence on the merits

level.toc-caption: [26,220.25] Other instances where the court may vary a judgment or order

heading.title: Other instances where the court may vary a judgment or order

row.entry: A general power to set aside or vary any order, whether or not part of a judgment, except so far as the order determines any claim for relief or dismisses proceedings

If application is made within 14 days after a judgment or order is entered, the court may determine the matter, and if appropriate, set aside or vary the judgment or order as if it had not been entered. The court may also act of its own motion within 14 days. This period may not be extended

Slip rule: The court may correct clerical mistakes, or errors arising from an an accidental slip or omission, in a judgment or order, or a certificate, on the application of a party or of its own motion

Party operating under unregistered business name: If judgment has been given or an order made against a person under a business name, the court may vary the judgment or order so as to make it a judgment or order against the person in the person’s own name

p.text: Legislation cited in [26,225] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 66, s 67.

row.entry: Adjournment — see:
CPA s 66
Stay of Proceedings, but only “permanently or until a specified day”.
CPA s 67

Note: There is no power to stay proceedings indefinitely. If a stay is sought until some specified event, such as the provision of security for costs, the necessary period should be ascertained and the matter stood over until the expiration of that period and the matter then revisited, if necessary
Appeals to the Supreme Court, see
Review of registrar’s directions, certificates, orders, decisions and other acts
All interlocutory or other applications to the court are to be made by motion unless the rules otherwise provide
The approved form of motion is
Form 20
A person may not move the court to make any order unless notice of motion has been filed and served on each person affected by the proposed order

Nominated exceptions are consent, the causing of under delay or prejudice, the court dispenses with the requirement of notice, practice of the court (eg. an application to arrest a person for disobedience of a subpoena; an application for urgent relief under
The formalities of a notice of motion are set out in

If the person making the application or against whom the application is made is already a party, the person must be so identified (plaintiff, defendant). Only a moving party who is not a party to the proceedings is to be described as a defendant, and only a person who is to be served with the motion who is not already a party is to be described as respondent
Costs need not be claimed in a notice of motion
A motion must state that the motion is to be dealt with in the absence of the public if it is a motion of that kind
ServiceThree days service of a notice of motion is required. Personal service is required where the person affected is not already an active party in the proceedings
Hearing of the motionOn the hearing of the motion, any party may make application in relation to the proceedings
Absent partyA motion may be dealt with in a party’s absence if the party has been served
DirectionsThe court may give directions as to the conduct of the proceedings

The formal requirements of an affidavit (heading, division into paragraphs, alterations, annexures and exhibits, inclusion of legal practitioner’s or Commissioner for Affidavit’s name, each page of the affidavit to be signed) are found at
The approved form of affidavit is
Form 40
The prescribed form of affidavit of service is
Form 41
The persons who may make an affidavit if a party is required to make an affidavit or verify any matter by affidavit are contained in

The rule encompasses the eligible deponents made on behalf of incapable persons, corporations, associations, represented persons, proceedings being brought in the plaintiff’s name by some other person pursuant to a right of subrogation and the Crown.
An irregularity does not invalidate an affidavit
Reasonable notice must be given of any requirement to cross-examine the deponent of an affidavit
Service — A party intending to use an affidavit must serve it on each other interested party within a reasonable time before it intended use

Filing of affidavits — An affidavit must not be filed unless it is filed in accordance with the Uniform Rules or other rules of court or a Practice Note (examples include applications for the signing of a default judgment (r 16.3) and affidavits for the issue of writs of execution (r 39.3))

The prescribed form is
Form 77
